pullRequest.body:
It's often desirable to get a concrete type in universe `Type u` that's order isomorphic to `o : Ordinal.{u}`. The way we've done this is by using the non-documented `(Quotient.out o).Î±`. We rename this to `Ordinal.toType o` for discoverability, and to hide what frankly should remain an implementation detail.

This also entails renaming a bunch of theorems that made reference to `out` in some form.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

This change reveals a lot of `typein ((Â· < Â·) : o.toType â†’ o.toType â†’ Prop)` in the code. A future refactor will replace this by the much more convenient `enumIsoToType`.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Ordinal.toType`
`+ card_typein_toType_lt`
`+ enumIsoToType`
`+ hasWellFounded_toType`
`+ initialSegToType`
`+ instance (o : Ordinal) : NoMaxOrder (aleph o).ord.toType`
`+ isEmpty_toType_zero`
`+ isWellOrder_toType_lt`
`+ linearOrder_toType`
`+ mk_Iio_ord_toType`
`+ mk_ord_toType`
`+ mk_toType`
`+ nonempty_toType_aleph`
`+ one_toType_eq`

`+ toType_noMax_of_succ_lt`
`+ toType_nonempty_iff_ne_zero`
`+ typein_one_toType`
`+ uniqueToTypeOne`
`- hasWellFoundedOut`
`- instance (o : Ordinal) : NoMaxOrder (aleph o).ord.out.Î±`
`- isEmpty_out_zero`
`- isWellOrder_out_lt`
`- linearOrderOut`
`- nonempty_out_aleph`
`- orderTopOutSucc`
`- uniqueOutOne`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
Why do we even have `o.toType`? Why don't we just use `Iio o` everywhere?

> Why do we even have `o.toType`? Why don't we just use `Iio o` everywhere?

There are some definitions that outright don't work without it, like `Ordinal.toPGame`, `PGame.nim`, or the future `Ordinal.toZFSet`. They all require an indexing type that lives within the same universe `u`. 

That said, `o.toType` is certainly overused in the current library, which is something I plan to address in a future refactor as I mention in my comment about `typein`.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10583933897/job/29327015605)
bors merge

Thanks!

maintainer merge
bors merge
If the plan moving forward is to prefer this correspondence over `typein` and `enum`, I think we should come up for a better name for it. What about `IioIsoToType`? Or even just `IsoToType`?
`IioOrderIsoToType` sounds very accurate. Shortenings of it might be fine
This porting note still applies, correct?
Yes, the universe has to be specified separately from the notation.
So shouldn't you keep the porting note?
Ah, my bad. Must have deleted it out of instinct.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(SetTheory/Ordinal/*): `o.out.Î±` â†’ `o.toType`

Why do we even have `o.toType`? Why don't we just use `Iio o` everywhere?

> Why do we even have `o.toType`? Why don't we just use `Iio o` everywhere?

There are some definitions that outright don't work without it, like `Ordinal.toPGame`, `PGame.nim`, or the future `Ordinal.toZFSet`. They all require an indexing type that lives within the same universe `u`. 

That said, `o.toType` is certainly overused in the current library, which is something I plan to address in a future refactor as I mention in my comment about `typein`.

Thanks!
